ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained some knowledge of different empires throughout history.
A broader understanding of how some Empires have shaped the world and the construction of nations as well as problems with the concept of naitonhood and decolonization.

Emphasis is placed on conceptual understandings and connections across modules as opposed to content. The syllabus spans disparate continents and historical eras like no other course; historical events, anecdotes and case studies are not meant to be memorized and studied extensively, but rather to be examined in the context of overarching ideas and observable patterns. It stands out in its breadth but allows students to focus on a case study of their choice for the midterm essay and final project in particular (so depth and breadth are achieved simultaneously).
Learned a lot of theories about empire and decolonization, which was really interesting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is very well-structured and the readings are engaging. The only weaknesses I would mention is the length of the readings: Sometimes they're too long to finish in a week.
Very conceptual and intellectually stimulating, but at times too fast-paced or extensive in terms of the content it spans to allow for an in-depth study of the empires examined.
Interesting readings, although a bit on the heavier side. But the workload is very manageable and both Wyrtzen and Sophia were awesome.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course if you want an overview of different empires throughout history. However, the class does not focus in-depth on a single empire, and so if you are looking for something more in-depth or detailed than this class isn't for you.
Definitely take this class. It is a not-so-strenuous history course where nevertheless you will learn so much.
I would! Prof. Wyrtzen has a great knowledge of what he teaches and has several references to expand one's knowledge.
Take this course if you are looking for breadth and an extensive, flexible final project. An absolute must for anyone interested in the political dynamics of a "post-colonial" world order.
Yes. It was very interesting and you're able to choose where you want to learn more and focus on.
